column1: How should resources be loaded form jar in Java?
Which option is a good way to handle the exception?
column2: @SneakyThrow%false|e.printStackTrace()%false|Rethrow with wrapping in business exception (for example, QuestionReadException)%true|Ignoring exception%false

column1: How is an ArrayList initialized in Java?
column2: ArrayList<String> list = new ArrayList<>()%true|List<String> list = new List<>()%false|ArrayList list = new ArrayList()%false|ArrayList<String> list = new ArrayList<String>()%false

column1: What is the purpose of the "static" keyword in Java?
column2: It indicates that a variable or method belongs to the class, not the instance.%true|It makes a variable or method non-modifiable.%false|It is used to create dynamic variables.%false|It ensures that a variable or method is accessible only within the same package.%false

column1: How do you declare an interface in Java?
column2: interface MyInterface {%true|interface MyInterfaceDeclaration {}%false|class MyInterface {}%false|interface MyInterface = {}%false|new interface MyInterface {}%false

column1: What is the purpose of the "super" keyword in Java?
column2: It is used to call the superclass methods or constructors.%true|It represents an instance of the current class.%false|It is used to access the static members of a class.%false|It is used to declare a super variable.%false

column1: How do you handle exceptions in Java?
column2: Using try-catch blocks to catch and handle exceptions.%true|By ignoring them to let the program crash.%false|By using the "throw" statement to propagate exceptions.%false|Exceptions are automatically handled by the Java Virtual Machine (JVM).%false
